title: Technology:  Solar  Developer  Nexamp  Gets Cash  Infusion  ----  By Luis Garcia
text:
Generate Capital, an investment firm focused on sustainable infrastructure, has invested $240 million in Nexamp Inc., as the solar developer looks to take advantage of a fast growing renewable-energy sector.

Boston-based Nexamp plans to use the capital to build more solar farms serving communities and businesses across the U.S., said the company's Chairman and Chief Executive Zaid Ashai.

The company recently signed a supply agreement with Walmart Inc. covering 23 community solar projects it owns across New York state. Roughly 50 megawatts, or 39%, of the projects' 129-megawatt total capacity will be allocated to the retailer, according to a press release announcing the deal.

Nexamp, which is backed by clean-energy company Diamond Generating Corp., decided to bring in a new investor partly to speed up its growth, Mr. Ashai said. In addition to the Generate investment, Nexamp earlier this year raised $440 million in debt financing from a group of lenders.

"We wanted to make sure that we have a robust balance sheet to address all the growth opportunities that we're seeing," Mr. Ashai said.

Nexamp's operating solar farms can generate more than 300 megawatts of electricity across 10 U.S. states and the company has about 700-megawatts in new projects in the works, according to a news release.

It is looking to expand beyond the states where it already operates, which include Georgia, Maine, Massachusetts, Maryland and New York, Mr. Ashai said.

He added that Nexamp can benefit from Generate's "different skill set" compared with Diamond, which focuses on solar- and wind-power generation as well as energy services.

San Francisco-based Generate, in turn, backs businesses and projects in a broader array of sectors linked to the economy's shift to clean energy, such as renewable energy, electric vehicles, water treatment and waste management.

Nexamp plans to offer services to its customers in addition to solar-power generation, as the company believes it can help them reduce carbon emissions in things other than their source of electricity, Mr. Ashai said.

"We're getting customers asking us questions like, 'I'm really happy with community solar. What can I do next?'" he said. "'How do I get rid of my gas car? How do I decarbonize my spending? How do I make my home more energy-efficient?'"

Mr. Ashai hopes the infrastructure bill making its way through Congress will help the U.S. revamp its power grid, as improvements are critical to the expansion of the so-called distributed-solar sector, or the kind of local, relatively small projects Nexamp develops.

The $1 trillion infrastructure bill shows that clean energy is a priority, but "bolder" steps are needed to boost the industry and address the threat of climate change, Mr. Ashai said.

For example, tax credits for renewable-energy development could be extended until the U.S. crosses a certain threshold for carbon reduction, he said.

"The infrastructure bill is a small drop in the bucket," Mr. Ashai said.
